Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2010 03:43AM Marie45 wrote: Thanks ladies, this makes total sense.  When I got the port installed in November, I was at peak weight from chemo.  At that time, I didn't notice the port being so shallow. I've since lost all the weight plus about 5 pounds - due to forgetting to eat and being busy, plus a weird fast heart thing. My normal was always 110.  I'm 5'3".  I'm now about 104.  It was in the past month or so that I lost the last 6 pounds and I started noticing the port pushing out of my skin.  I guess if I put on some pounds maybe it will no longer protrude. Thanks for your wisdom!! Oh!  I almost forgot to ask....how does it come out?  It was put in when I had my mastectomy surgery.  Do you need to have to be 'put out'?  I would seem to me you would have to be...
Posts.Title: Shallow Port Marie45 ruthbru

Posts.Content: Marie45 wrote: Does anyone have a shallow port?  I had mine intalled in November and it is very shallow.  You can see it slightly elevated above the skin.  When it was first installed, it wasn't raised above the skin, but still it was shallow and in the past 6 weeks or so, it become slightly elevated. Heavy necklaces bang on it and it hurts.  When I try and sleep on my stomach, if I am leaning on it, it hurts. The Oncology nurses in the treatment room haven't mentioned anything so I guess it's normal but what about neclaces and stomach sleeping.  Is that just a no? Thanks. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Shallow Port Marie45 ruthbru

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2010 06:18PM Marie45 wrote: ruth you are right about details.  My Onc said to have surgery in November '09 and said I would then be on Herceptin for two years.  I don't know if he meant two years from the surgery or two years total becaue I was taking it combined with Taxotere from about May '09 so it'll be in until May 2011 at the earliest or Nov 2011.  I asked him if I was going to be two more years in treatment, then maybe I should get a port while I have my mastectomy.  He said 'Good idea'.  Good thing I thought of it because it sounded like he wasn't going to. Oh my goodness!  Good thing I like Yogurt!!
Posts.Title: Shallow Port Marie45 ruthbru

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2010 09:22PM Marie45 wrote: It seems general thinking is that one year is where a patient gets the most benefit from Herceptin.  More or less doesn't seem to be any more beneficial. I live in Canada and my Medical Oncologist believes Herceptin is too new of a drug to say definitively that 1 year is where the maximum benefit of Herception to the patient lies.  For me he said 2 years but every three months I need a chest/abdomen/pelvis CT scan and a Muga scan otherwise the government won't dole out the drug.  When you say 52 weeks, do you mean once a week?  My two years is once every three weeks like my chemo always was.
Posts.Title: Shallow Port Marie45 ruthbru

Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2009 01:07AM Marie45 wrote: notinvincible, I was diagnosed November 20, 2008.  I was where you are.  Nutshell: I was diagnosed with a 6cm x 8cm invasive tumour in my left breast - Grade 3 plus there was a cancer in a duct just sitting there. I am Her2+, Er-/Pr- I got a picc line in and did 6 rounds of FEC, 9 rounds of Taxotere and Herceptin then one round of Herceptin only in preparation for surgery.  The chemo shrunk the tumour down to the point neither my Medical Oncologist, Surgeon or Surgical Resident could really feel it. November 20 (last month), I had a simple left breast mastectomy with no reconstruction plus I had a port a catheter implanted and the picc line removed.  Immediately after surgery my surgeon said it was mostly scar tissue in there and what else she saw wasn't anything she hadn't seen a million times.  I asked that my Pathology go to my Medical Oncologist.  It came back and I didn't want to know the detail.  I find I am the type of patient that works best with minimal information.  My Medical Oncologist says he was happy with my Pathology report.  I've had bone scans, MRI's, CT scans and Muga scans every three months all year long and it looks like that will go on for years.  I thought something was going to show up on my bones as well because my right hip bone had been sore on and off for years.  My bone scans have all been fine.  I am set for two years of Herceptin treatment.  My 'first one' of those was December 22nd. A mantra that works for me: 'I Can Do This',.  I didn't tell my kids (16 and 14) at the time until all my test results were back and I knew exactly what I was dealing with.  I ultimately told them about two weeks before Christmas last year.  There is no answer to 'why me'?  I have searched for that.  Take it one day at a time.
Posts.Title: Just diadnosed and petrified SPoole Frankie_

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2009 04:21PM Marie45 wrote: Hi skimmingthelake, I live in Canada.  My Medical Oncologist is doing a study on Herceptin's effectiveness.  It is still a relatively new drug and to date, general practice/thinking is that one year has been determined to be the 'most effective' timeline for the use of the drug.  He says because the drug is still new, that's not 'been proven' so he wants me on it for two years.  I've heard of others (don't know them, just hear about them from the Onc nurses) that some are on a four year program for Herceptin.
Posts.Title: Just diadnosed and petrified SPoole Frankie_

Posts.Content: Marie45 wrote: I took 6 rounds of FEC then 9 rounds of Taxotere with Herceptin.  That ended mid-Octobr 2009 but I continue on with Herceptin every three weeks for a couple of years. My leg muscles are so weak.  I walk like a Granny - okay it's better now, but still not a normal person pace.  I used to need to haul myself upstairs with my arms.  I can now go up a flight of stairs without holding the rail now but I'm slow, and not 'light on my feet'.  I went back to my dance class and can only move my legs at about half time to the music. When I get up from sitting, I'm all stiff in the legs.  Once I get moving it's not so bad.  When I gained all the weight from Chemo, I was afraid I would never lose it but I did.  Now I'm afraid my Taxotere 'Legs' will never go away.  The bottom of my feet are numb but it's not a big deal.   My Onc doesn't know how long this will last as he says everyone is different.  I'm hoping there are some ladies here who can relate their experience.  There was a Taxotere thread somewhere but it's old and there wasn't much on the leg thing,  Has anyone ever recovered from Taxotere 'Legs'?? Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Taxotere 'Legs' Marie45 lovetosail

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2010 10:18PM Marie45 wrote: Thanks!  This news is somewhat encouraging.  There is reason to be hopeful! I didn't see the TC thread but I don't know what the 'C' is.  I don't think I've taken 'C' unless its something called Cytomyacin (sp?) but I'm pretty sure it's Taxotere that does this. Maybe I'll be more earnest with the stairs.  I went back to my belly dance class but can only move half time to the music. I'm 46 and was 110 pounds before chemo, then I was 146 when chemo ended.  I took furosemide to get rid of the water weight but the weight fell off and now I'm 103-105 trying desperately to gain weight.  I realize now though that I don't look emaciated and was 103-105 before my kids so maybe I shouldn't panic about weight.  At 110 I had 'muffin tops' and now I don't so again, maybe I shouldn't whine! I am having a terrible time with shoes.   I used to be a 3" heel 'shoeaholic'.  Since around spring '09 I've only been able to wear these super cheap and flexible flats from Target - ONE pair only!!  My toenails got thick and ridgey and half of my left big toenail popped off about 2 months ago.  The top of my toes feel weird when I try shoes on. I'm hoping I can maybe handle a wedge for spring/summer but it's weird with numb feet and 'weak' feeling ankles, leg muscles etc..  anything other than those flats seems to tire the feet. Thanks for your experience.  Sometimes I feel like I am the only one with this!!
Posts.Title: Taxotere 'Legs' Marie45 lovetosail
